claim: Mount Everest is the tallest mountain above sea level

supporting.text: Mount Everest's summit elevation of 8,848 meters above sea level is the highest confirmed by modern geodetic surveys.

attacks.text: Mount Everest's summit elevation of 8,848 meters above sea level is the highest confirmed by modern geodetic surveys.
Mauna Kea's total height from base to summit is approximately 10,210 meters, though much of it is underwater.
The claim specifies 'above sea level,' so Mauna Kea's underwater portion is irrelevant to the comparison.
Chimborazo's summit is the farthest point from Earth's center due to equatorial bulge, making it 'taller' in that sense.
The claim explicitly refers to height above sea level, not distance from Earth's center.

supporting.text: No other mountain on Earth has been measured to exceed Mount Everest's height above sea level in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

attacks.text: No other mountain on Earth has been measured to exceed Mount Everest's height above sea level in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

The claim specifically refers to height above sea level, not base-to-summit height, so Mauna Kea's measurement is irrelevant to this comparison.
Satellite measurements have suggested K2 might be taller than Everest, but these claims lack peer-reviewed verification.
Unverified satellite measurements do not meet the scientific standard required to challenge Everest's established height.

supporting.text: The International Mountaineering and Climbing Federation (UIAA) recognizes Mount Everest as the highest peak above sea level.

attacks.text: The International Mountaineering and Climbing Federation (UIAA) recognizes Mount Everest as the highest peak above sea level.
The UIAA's recognition is based on traditional sea-level measurements, but modern geodesy suggests alternative reference points (e.g., geoid-based elevation) that could yield different rankings.
Geoid-based elevation models still overwhelmingly confirm Everest's supremacy, with measurement uncertainties far smaller than the height difference to the second-highest peak.
Mauna Kea's height from base to summit exceeds Everest's when measured from its underwater base, challenging the 'above sea level' framing as arbitrary.
The claim explicitly specifies 'above sea level', making Mauna Kea's total height irrelevant to this particular comparison.

supporting.text: National Geographic and other authoritative geographic institutions consistently list Mount Everest as the tallest mountain above sea level.

attacks.text: National Geographic and other authoritative geographic institutions consistently list Mount Everest as the tallest mountain above sea level.
Some argue that Mauna Kea is taller when measured from its base on the ocean floor, challenging the definition of 'above sea level'.
The standard geographic definition of mountain height universally uses sea level as the baseline, making Mauna Kea's base irrelevant for this comparison.
Satellite measurements in 2020 suggested Everest's height might be slightly less than previously recorded due to snowpack variability.
The 2020 China-Nepal joint survey confirmed Everest's height as 8,848.86m, resolving previous measurement discrepancies.

supporting.text: Satellite and ground-based measurements from multiple countries confirm Mount Everest's height as the highest above sea level.

attacks.text: Satellite and ground-based measurements from multiple countries confirm Mount Everest's height as the highest above sea level.
Sea level is not a fixed reference point globally due to variations in Earth's geoid and local tidal effects, making 'above sea level' an imprecise metric.
Modern geodesy accounts for geoid variations by using standardized global reference models like WGS84, ensuring consistent sea-level-based measurements.
Mauna Kea's height from base to summit exceeds Everest's, but most is submerged, challenging the 'above sea level' definition's relevance.
The claim explicitly specifies 'above sea level,' making Mauna Kea's submerged base irrelevant to the comparison.

supporting.text: Mount Everest's elevation is officially recognized by both Nepal and China, the countries it straddles.

attacks.text: Mount Everest's elevation is officially recognized by both Nepal and China, the countries it straddles.
Official recognition by governments does not necessarily reflect objective geological measurements.
Nepal and China use internationally accepted surveying methods to determine Everest's height, ensuring objectivity.
